questions.text: A Patient undergoing surgery for tubotympanic disease. After surgery he developed vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, tinnitus etc. what is most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is perilymph fistula. This is a condition where there is a tear in the membrane that separates the inner ear from the middle ear. This can cause vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus.

  • Labyrinthitis:This is an inflammation of the inner ear, but it is usually not associated with surgery. The patient in this question has already undergone surgery, so labyrinthitis is less likely.
  • Paget disease:This is a rare bone disorder that can affect the skull, but it does not usually cause these symptoms. The patient in this question is experiencing vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus, which are not typical symptoms of Paget disease.
  • Lateral vein thrombophlebitis:This is a blood clot in a vein in the ear, but it is also not usually associated with these symptoms. The patient in this question is experiencing vertigo, fluctuating hearing loss, and tinnitus, which are not typical symptoms of lateral vein thrombophlebitis.

questions.text: What is the structure being shown with the arrow in the given CT SCAN image?
questions.solution:
The structure shown with the arrow in the CT scan image is: Onodi cell

The Onodi cell, also known as the sphenoethmoidal cell, is a type of paranasal sinus cell that is located posteriorly and superiorly to the sphenoid sinus.

It is located just above the sphenoid sinus and can be closely related to important structures such as the optic nerve and carotid artery.

  1. Agger nasi: The agger nasi cell is located anteriorly to the ethmoid sinus, near the frontal recess, and is not represented by the arrow in the image.
  2. Concha bullosa: Concha bullosa is a pneumatized middle turbinate, and it is not the structure shown in the image.
  3. Haller cell: Haller cell is an infraorbital ethmoid air cell and is not represented by the arrow in the image.

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with right sided reddish pink nasal mass and epistaxis. CT Scan image is given in the picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Inverted papilloma: It is a benign sinonasal tumor that arises from the Schneiderian membrane lining the nasal cavity. It appears as a pinkish mass with inverted growth pattern and can cause epistaxis (nosebleeds) due to its location and vascular supply. It is commonly seen in adults and has a tendency to recur after surgical removal.

A. Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a vascular tumor that occurs in young males and is usually located in the posterior nasal cavity and nasopharynx. It is not the most probable diagnosis based on the CT scan image provided.

C. Maxillary carcinoma:This is a type of cancer that can affect the maxilla, which is the upper jawbone. The patient in this question is experiencing symptoms that are more consistent with a tumor in the nose or sinuses, so maxillary carcinoma is not a likely diagnosis.

D. Ethmoid carcinoma:This is a type of cancer that can affect the ethmoid sinuses. The patient in this question is experiencing symptoms that are more consistent with a tumor in the nose or sinuses, so ethmoid carcinoma is not a likely diagnosis.

questions.text:
A Child with bilateral Anotia. Which hearing aid implant is used?
A.
B.
C.
D.
questions.solution:
Bone-Anchored Hearing Aid (Baha)

Baha is the most suitable option for individuals with bilateral anotia. Bilateral anotia means the absence of external ears on both sides. In such cases, conventional hearing aids cannot be worn due to the lack of ear structures to hold them in place. Cochlear implant surgery typically requires access to the cochlea, which is challenging in the absence of external ears and middle ear structures.

Baha, on the other hand, is designed to bypass the middle ear and directly stimulate the inner ear using bone conduction. It involves implanting a small titanium fixture into the skull bone behind the ear. The sound processor is then attached to this fixture, and sound vibrations are transmitted through bone conduction to the cochlea, enabling the sensation of hearing. Since Baha does not require external ears or a functional middle ear, it is a more suitable option for individuals with bilateral anotia.

b) Cochlear Implant

Cochlear implants are not the most suitable option for bilateral anotia. Cochlear implants require the insertion of an electrode array directly into the cochlea to stimulate the auditory nerve. However, in cases of bilateral anotia, there are no external ears or a normal middle ear structure to facilitate the placement of the electrode array.

c) Electrode Array

An electrode array is a component of a cochlear implant and cannot be used as a standalone solution for individuals with bilateral anotia.

d) TORP (Total Ossicular Replacement Prosthesis)

TORP is a middle ear implant used to reconstruct the ossicular chain in cases of middle ear pathologies, particularly those affecting the ossicles (bones of the middle ear). It is not a suitable option for individuals with bilateral anotia, as it does not address the absence of external ears or the direct stimulation of the inner ear.

questions.text: Post complete laryngectomy all advised/done except?
questions.solution:
After a complete laryngectomy, the patient will need a way to produce speech. The most common methods are an electrolarynx, a tracheo-esophageal fistula, or esophageal speech.

Supra tracheal prosthesis / fistula is not a method of speech production that is used after a complete laryngectomy.

A. Electrolarynx: An electrolarynx is an electronic device held against the neck that produces sound when activated, providing an artificial voice.

B. Tracheo -Esophageal fistula (TEF): TEF is a surgical technique that creates a connection between the trachea (windpipe) and the esophagus. This allows air to be diverted into the esophagus, and the patient can use the upper esophageal sphincter to create speech sounds. It is a common method of post-laryngectomy voice rehabilitation.

D. Esophageal speech: Esophageal speech is a technique where the patient swallows air and then regurgitates it while shaping the mouth and pharynx to produce speech sounds.
